arm_group.description: Turn off after 10 s of stimulation

brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the analgesic effect of transcranial direct current
      stimulation (tDCS) applied on motor cortex in patients with spinal cord injury who have
      chronic neuropathic pain.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Effects of Transcranial Direct Current Stimulation on Central Pain in Patients With Spinal Cord Injury

detailed_description.textblock:
-  anodal stimulation of the primary motor cortex (M1)

        -  anode electrode: C3 (EEG 10/20 system)

        -  cathode electrode: contralateral supraorbital area

        -  constant current of 2mA intensity for 20 min

        -  twice a day with a more than 4 hours interval during of 2 weeks (from Monday to Friday,
           total 20 treatment session)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  elapsed time since spinal cord injury more than 6 months

          -  stable chronic pain for at least 3 preceding months

          -  pain that was not attributable to cause other that neuropathic pain

          -  pain that was resistant to various types of medications or physical or complementary
             medicine treatment

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  any kind of metal implant in the head

          -  heart disease including having a cardiac maker

          -  family or personal history of epilepsy, or neuropsychiatric illness

clinical_study.official_title: The Analgesic Effect of Transcranial Direct Current Stimulation Over the Primary Motor Cortex on Central Neuropathic Pain Patients With Spinal Cord Injury

other_outcome.measure: Pain interference in general daily life, mood and sleep
other_outcome.time_frame: before the first tDCS session, and 1, 2, 4, 6, 8 wk after start of the stimulation

primary_outcome.measure: Numeric rating scale for average pain over the preceding 24h
primary_outcome.time_frame: before the first tDCS session, and 1, 2, 4, 6 and 8 wk after the start of the stimulation
